discussion.content: Correct answer should be A & D. Since B is required max overhead.

comments.content: Also, what are the chances a network administrator can physically configure "all" guest devices to use static IP addresses?

discussion.content: "configure visitors devices to use static IP" - I'm a desktop engineer for 5 years, this answer seems like a joke to me ..
Answer B is just absolutely ridiculous lol. No way in hell this should have been 1 of the answers

Selected Answer: AD
Why would give a static address for guests... One of the answers is wrong!

Selected Answer: AD
Static IP for guest...okay no
How the heck are we gonna get static IPs on guest’s devices? “B” makes no sense to me.

PassLeader has this question listed a couple of times. One of them shows the answer as being A+D (SSID+Mixed Mode). 
Explanation on Passleader is: "You want your guests to be able to ID the correct WiFi netowrk and use a secure login whcih would be a WPA2. Unless you want to sit there all day everyday and enter visitors IP addresses manually B does not make any sense then."
So ensuring the access point is not running in mixed mode has more overhead configuration that configuring EVERY devices for static IP? Oh okay comptia.
A static IP is useful for a webserver not for wifi
Sounds like this is a CompTIA throw away question.
Answers A & D seems the most logical.

Answer should be A and D. Static ip configuration is the one who offers more configuration overhead LOL. A and D is basically turning the device on, configuring basic stuff like SSID and DHCP pool and a password.
The only way I can see B is that it needs to be on a separate network and wants us to set a static dhcp range for the guest network to use in a separate subnet perhaps.
A and D definitely!
My immediate assumption was A and D. You know what? It still is.

comments.content: E is for enviroments when you know you have devices on the 2.4Ghz and the 5Ghz, it's mixed. You don't your guests and what are they using.

discussion.content: Why not A and E?
A&D should be the correct answers.
Agreed!

choices.E: Ensure the access point is not running in mixed mode
choices.B: Configure visitor devices to use static IP addresses
choices.A: Enable SSID broadcasting to identify the guest network
choices.C: Enable two-factor authentication on visitor devices
choices.D: Configure the access point to use WPA2-AES encryption

questions.question_text:
A technician is setting up a public guest network for visitors to access the Internet that must be separate from the corporate network. Which of the following are the
BEST steps for the technician to take with minimum overhead configuration? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: ST is Twist

If you go back to question 67, the connection was ST (from the fiber patch panel, they said it was a circular connection) to SC (transceiver on the switch that accepted a square adapter of two stands). ST and SC seem to be the standard, where ST is round and twisted.

I believe the confusion here lies with the fact that the question is incomplete in that it should be asking you to choose 2 options out of the 5. If the patch panel has ST connections (twist) and the new switch interface is via an SFP (LC connecter), you would use an ST to LC cable. Google "LC ST Patch Cable".
Why cant we just have the full names of each

The ST connector was one of the first connector types widely implemented in fiber optic networking applications. Originally developed by AT&T, it stands for Straight Tip connector. ST connections use a 2.5mm ferrule with a round plastic or metal body. The connector stays in place with a "twist-on/twist-off" bayonet-style mechanism. Although extremely popular for many years, the ST connector is slowly being supplanted by smaller, denser connections in many installations.
Theside with the Patch panel already connect the question states "replacing a switch" the Question is related to the Switch side only.
ST (Straight Tip) connections twist similar to BNC

B is correct.

ST connectors: These connectors are the most common type of commercial fiber optic connector. These connectors utilize an exposed plastic tube housing the optical fiber. This requires a connection to a matching cable on the other side, incorporating a connector that mates to the other. These combine in a spring-loaded twist, reminiscent of BNC connectors, and are noted for their reliability. ST connector is very popular in communication applications, such as LANs and CCTV systems.

The question is incomplete!!! Because patch panel side the correct answer is ST (Twist-type),
but SFP side the correct answer is LC. The question don't specificate the side.
Twist-Style is like the BNC remember, the only one who fitted was ST
I believe the "twisted-style" they are referring to is the BNC plug the ST uses.

comments.content: SC is a square plug though LoL

discussion.content:
The given answer is correct: 
 SC connectors also use a round 2.5mm ferrule to hold a single fiber. They use a push-on/pull-off mating mechanism which is generally easier to use than the twist-style ST connector when in tight spaces.

https://www.cablestogo.com/learning/connector-guides/fiber-networking
twist-style SC connector

comments.content: This is exactly what I was thinking

It seems Nmap is creating some confusion here as its states are defined a bit different. But even in case of considering Nmap to be our port scanner, then choice C is closer to the answer, rather than choice B.
Since the question has not specified 'Nmap', choice A is the Best.

discussion.content:
A is correct. If you send an SYN packet to a closed port, an RST flag will be sent back.
“When a port is closed, RFC 793 behavior is to respond with an RST “reset” packet.”

When a port scanner is used, several port states may be reported:
1. Open/listening: The host sent a reply indicating that a service is listening on
the port. There was a response from the port.
2. Closed or denied or not listening: No process is listening on that port.
Access to this port will likely be denied.
3. Filtered or blocked: There was no reply from the host, meaning that the
port is not listening or the port is secured and filtered.

When a port is closed, no process is listening on that port and access to
this port will likely be denied. When the port is open/listening, the host sends
a reply indicating that a service is listening on the port. When the port is
filtered or blocked, there is no reply from the host, meaning that the port is
not listening or the port is secured and filtered.
The answer should be A . not B.

B is correct.
"A closed port is accessible (it receives and responds to Nmap probe packets), but there is no application listening on it... Administrators may want to consider blocking such ports with a firewall. Then they would appear in the filtered state, discussed next.

filtered
Nmap cannot determine whether the port is open because packet filtering prevents its probes from reaching the port."

So if it was A, then it would show up as "filtered" rather than "closed".

Answer - B is correct

https://www.wise-geek.com/what-is-a-closed-port.htm#

I see no reason why a deprecated service wouldn't respond to a port scan the same way it always responded. Deprecation doesn't mean something doesn't work anymore, it's just that there's usually a newer version.
If they were denaying requests, i think it will show "filtering"
Depracated means that somethin can be reached but it doesn't respond, so it justifies the answer to be B.

B is correct. Popular port scanner "Nmap" defines a closed port as follows:

"A closed port is accessible (it receives and responds to Nmap probe packets), but there is no application listening on it."

comments.content: No application as in no services is associated with such port. A is the right answer. My previous cert buddies agreed too

discussion.content: question says he used a port scanner

choices.A: The ports belong to an active system and are denying requests
choices.D: The ports replied with a SYN/ACK response
choices.B: The ports are associated with deprecated services
choices.C: The ports do not belong to a live system
